conclusion: The problem involves analyzing forces acting on a piston and gas inside a thermally conductive cylinder in an elevator, using principles of conservation of energy and pressure-volume relationships for an ideal gas.
The initial pressure inside the cylinder is equal to the atmospheric pressure plus the pressure due to the weight of the piston.
The force due to the weight of the piston is calculated as \( mg \), and the pressure due to the weight of the piston is \( \frac{mg}{S} \).
The initial pressure inside the cylinder \( P_1 \) is calculated as \( P_0 + \frac{mg}{S} = 1.01 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \).
The maximum tension in the rope is given as \( F = 120 \text{ N} \).
The weight of the cylinder and the piston is calculated as \( (M + m)g = 75 \text{ N} \).
The force exerted by the gas on the piston is \( P_2 S \), where \( P_2 \) is the final pressure inside the cylinder.
The maximum tension is expressed as \( F = P_2 S - (M + m)g \), and solving for \( P_2 \) gives \( P_2 = \frac{F + (M + m)g}{S} = 6.5 \times 10^3 \text{ Pa} \).
The initial volume of the gas is calculated as \( V_1 = L_1 S \), where \( L_1 = 19 \text{ cm} = 0.19 \text{ m} \).
The final volume of the gas is expressed as \( V_2 = L_2 S \), where \( L_2 \) is the final distance from the piston to the bottom of the cylinder.
Using the relationship \( P_1 V_1 = P_2 V_2 \), it is derived that \( L_2 = \frac{P_1 L_1}{P_2} \).

Substituting the values \( P_1 = 1.01 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \), \( P_2 = 6.5 \times 10^3 \text{ Pa} \), and \( L_1 = 0.19 \text{ m} \), the maximum distance \( L_2 \) is calculated as \( 2.944 \text{ m} \).
